title: Multi-Cloud IAM Token Theft Campaign Targeting Enterprise Environments

timeline.event: First signs of coordinated IAM token theft campaign detected
Multiple enterprises report unauthorized cloud access
Attribution to APT group with nation-state ties
Joint advisory released by CISA and cloud providers
Active exploitation continues; new TTPs identified

simple_summary.what_happened: A sophisticated threat actor is running a large-scale campaign to steal cloud access tokens from enterprises. They target identity providers and cloud credentials stored on developer workstations. Once they have tokens, they access AWS, Azure, and GCP resources across multiple organizations.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Enterprise organizations using multiple cloud providers, especially those with federated identity (SSO) between on-premises and cloud environments. Companies using HashiCorp Vault, Okta, or similar identity solutions are primary targets.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Phishing campaign targets IT administrators and developers. Step 2: Malware harvests stored cloud credentials and tokens. Step 3: Attackers enumerate cloud resources across all linked providers. Step 4: They establish persistent access via new IAM users/roles. Step 5: Data exfiltration and ransomware deployment begins.
what_you_should_do: Enforce MFA on all cloud console and API access immediately
Review and rotate all service account credentials
Check for unauthorized IAM users, roles, and access keys
Enable cloud provider threat detection services
Search for indicators of compromise in identity provider logs
Implement conditional access policies based on device and location
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Identity is the new perimeter in cloud environments. With valid tokens, attackers can access anything those credentials can access - databases, storage, compute, and secrets. Multi-cloud environments multiply the attack surface, and a single compromised identity can lead to breaches across all your cloud providers.

tactics.description: Targeted phishing emails deliver credential-stealing malware
Malware harvests cloud provider tokens from workstations
Attackers create new cloud accounts for persistent access
Attackers enumerate cloud resources across multiple providers

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for unusual IAM activity across all cloud providers. Look for new principals, cross-account access, and API calls from unexpected locations. Correlate identity provider logs with cloud access logs.

log_sources.description: All AWS API calls including IAM and STS operations
IAM policy changes and admin activity
Okta, Azure AD, or other IdP authentication logs

what_to_look_for.description: Creation of IAM principals outside normal processes
Same identity accessing resources from geographically distant locations
AssumeRole calls with unusual user agents or from unexpected IPs
Rapid API calls to list resources across multiple services
what_to_look_for.log_field: eventName LIKE 'List%' OR eventName LIKE 'Describe%' high frequency

immediate_actions.description: Enforce multi-factor authentication on all cloud console and API access
List all users, roles, and service accounts created in the last 30 days
Check for and revoke suspicious active sessions in Azure AD
Ensure AWS GuardDuty, Azure Sentinel, and GCP Security Command Center are active
